content.webTitle: Johanna Konta’s scorching Venus victory forged on tough, tearful midwinter nights

fields.headline: Johanna Konta’s scorching Venus victory forged on tough, tearful midwinter nights
fields.bodyText: The measure of Johanna Konta’s greatest victory to date – a quick, clinical win over Venus Williams on her debut in the main draw of the Australian Open – is there to see in the statistics and the performance. But that is just the visible tip of a story far from finished. It might have taken the world No47 only an hour and 19 minutes to dismiss the oldest player in the women’s draw on a warm afternoon – and there could be no downplaying the emphatic 6-4, 6-2 scoreline – but hers was a triumph fashioned in midwinter, on cold, wet London nights when she was reduced to tears on the practice court through the grinding effort of repeated drills, yet begging for more hard yards to refine her excellent tennis. Her prize is a much easier assignment on Thursday against China’s Saisai Zheng, who played way above her world ranking of 83 to demolish the German world No62, Carina Witthoeft, 6-1, 6-2 in an hour and a quarter. It will not be a respite, more a return to normality, and Konta should win again. “I actually played her a few years ago at French Open qualifiers,” said Zheng. “That was a long time ago. Last year in Wuhan she played really well. So I think she will be really tough opponent.” If Konta needed a further lifting of the spirit the No2 seed, Simona Halep fell later to the Chinese qualifier Shuai Zhang, who registered her first grand slam win in 15 attempts. So, the fairway for Konta is wide, with few bunkers and only self-made hazards. She did not arrive here by accident. Her precision, her determination to “stay in the moment” was glaringly at odds with the distracted resignation of her garlanded opponent. Konta deserved to win because Williams was powerless to stop her and, ultimately, she looked drained of desire. As the British No1 recalled: “During my pre-season, after day two I was just tired every single day. It didn’t matter what we were doing. Even if I had a day off I was so tired. It takes a lot out of you. And, after you’ve put so much work in, then it is about finding your feet again out on the match court. “It’s a different ball game all together. The biggest thing that the pre-season does for you is to maximise your chance of playing a full season, of putting yourself in such a physical condition that you’re able to rely on that during some very difficult conditions in matches. “ I don’t actually hate anything about training – I’m complaining about it, but in a good-hearted way; I thank my lucky stars that I get to train hard as a job. But it’s not nice in the moment and, trust me, there are tears, because when I get tired I usually cry. But you learn to love it. One of my previous coaches used to talk about getting comfortable with being uncomfortable, and that’s very true. “In every aspect of this sport you get thrown into some very uncomfortable situations that are about letting go and feeling at home. In week four of the off-season we were doing interval training on court and my tolerance was head height and my mood was about ceiling height. I had a moment, a bit of a breakdown, so my coach said: ‘OK, we’ll only do 15 seconds.’ But I was, like: ‘No! We keep it at 30 seconds – I’m not crying for you to make this easier, I just need to let this out!’” And so 12,000 miles away in the first slam of the season she found herself looking across the net at Williams, who has won seven grand slams, who reached the final here 13 years ago, who had fought back from illness to return to the top 10 for the first time in five years and who still represented a genuine threat. “This was definitely the biggest stage I’ve won on, as it was on Rod Laver. In terms of a decorated tennis player and the biggest champion I’ve ever played, yeah, she definitely is. And I’m very proud of the way I was able to stay very present and just keep going, whatever the scoreline.” The match was not without its anxious moments, particularly when Williams broke trailing 0-5 in the second and started to build a little comeback energy. But staying “very present”, as Konta puts it, has been the defining change in her tennis over the past year or so. “When the ebbs and flows of matches go like that, it’s very important to put things in perspective, to be very honest with yourself and say: ‘Listen, if it does go 5-5 will the world implode? Not exactly.’ “While our emotions are running high and there is obviously a lot of adrenalin and things can get a bit tense, it is just a tennis match. Also, you have to realise she played very well [in the second set]. She made very few errors in those two games and was serving incredibly well to hold at 5-1.” But clearly not well enough. There was a gulf that was visible to everyone on the tournament’s main court. Those who might not have been familiar with Konta or her journey (even though she was born in Sydney) surely were aware they were witnessing the dismantling of a once-great player, the oldest in the tournament but still a Williams sister. For much of the match, it was one-sided. It would be illuminating to hear what the loser thought of the experience, perhaps what she thought of Konta’s game and her prospects over the rest of the fortnight. But the American, who can be stubbornly aloof when the mood takes her, refused to come to the mandatory press conference and indicated she was happy to accept the fine. The maximum penalty for her recalcitrance is $20,000 but her fine is more likely to be closer to the $3,000 she incurred for a similar offence at Roland Garros last year.
